title: Genome-editing record smashed with 13,000 edits made in one cell
description: A team led by George Church has used CRISPR to make a record number of DNA changes in one cell, taking us a step closer to thoroughly re-writing our genomes

Manage your subscription here Activate subscription            Genome-editing record smashed with 13,000 edits made in one cell          Health   26 March 2019     CRISPR gene editing changes the sequence of DNA CARLOS CLARIVAN/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY By Michael Le Page A team has used CRISPR to make a record-breaking 13,200 changes to the DNA of a single human cell. The feat takes us a step closer to being able to thoroughly rewrite the genomes of our cells and other organisms. Half of our genomes – the complete set of DNA inside our cells – consist of hundreds of thousands of copies of genetic parasites called transposons.
